input: question: Who urged Liu Bang to become emperor? [SEP] sentence: Two former rebel leaders, Xiang Yu (d. 202 BC) of Chu and Liu Bang (d. 195 BC) of Han, engaged in a war to decide who would become hegemon of China, which had fissured into 18 kingdoms, each claiming allegiance to either Xiang Yu or Liu Bang.

question: Which country has Nigerians sending the second-most money home? [SEP] sentence: According to the International Organization for Migration, Nigeria witnessed a dramatic increase in remittances sent home from overseas Nigerians, going from USD 2.3 billion in 2004 to 17.9 billion in 2007.

question: Why was the word "national" a cause for alarm to both Federalists and Anti-Federalists? [SEP] sentence: Some legal scholars, such as John Baker of LSU, theorize that Madison's initial proposed language—that Congress should make no law regarding the establishment of a "national religion"—was rejected by the House, in favor of the more general "religion" in an effort to appease the Anti-Federalists.
question: Who wrote Epistolae? [SEP] sentence: Almost all the books published in Paris in the Middle Ages were in Latin, rather than French.

question: What other popular music player did Apple compare their new product to? [SEP] sentence: Digital cameras, camcorders and organizers had well-established mainstream markets, but the company found existing digital music players "big and clunky or small and useless" with user interfaces that were "unbelievably awful," so Apple decided to develop its own.
question: Which group became extinct after living in the region for about 12,000 years? [SEP] sentence: Homo floresiensis also lived in the area up until 12,000 years ago, when they became extinct.

question: How many buses does the London public bus network operate? [SEP] sentence: The distinctive red double-decker buses are an internationally recognised trademark of London transport along with black cabs and the Tube.
question: Why did Squeeze LDs have a very limited market? [SEP] sentence: Since very few people owned 16:9 displays, the marketability of these special discs was very limited.
question: What new capital was founded in 1650, lower Egypt? [SEP] sentence: The Hyksos invaders took over much of Lower Egypt around 1650 BC and founded a new capital at Avaris.
question: What did Albert study in Trinity College? [SEP] sentence: In October 1919, Albert went up to Trinity College, Cambridge, where he studied history, economics and civics for a year.
question: What is the name of the surviving monastic building in England? [SEP] sentence: The living and working parts of many monastic buildings survive, for example at Mont Saint-Michel.

question: What type of lifestyle was prevalent in Siberia until the European Age of Discovery? [SEP] sentence: Hunter-gathering lifestyles remained prevalent in some parts of the New World, Sub-Saharan Africa, and Siberia, as well as all of Australia, until the European Age of Discovery.

question: What company had a partnership with The Walt Disney Company for The American Idol Experience? [SEP] sentence: On February 14, 2009, The Walt Disney Company debuted "The American Idol Experience" at its Disney's Hollywood Studios theme park at the Walt Disney World Resort in Florida.
question: What is not often aspirated? [SEP] sentence: Voiced consonants are seldom actually aspirated.
question: What is a cost of nocturnal migration? [SEP] sentence: Migrants may be able to alter their quality of sleep to compensate for the loss.

question: What morphological features do forensic anthropologists draw on? [SEP] sentence: Similarly, forensic anthropologists draw on highly heritable morphological features of human remains (e.g. cranial measurements) to aid in the identification of the body, including in terms of race.
